audio_caption: The audio clip commences with dramatic and building orchestral music evoking a sense of grandiosity.  A male speaker is then introduced who sounds like a Professor, stating, "Hello this is professor Jim Caffey and today we are doing the next to last lecture in our 30 chapter series called 10 minute astronomy for the Open Stacks astronomy free textbook." He then introduces chapter 29 which, "is called the Big Bang are you ready? Okay, here we go." The speech continues in an informative manner stating, "Prepare to have your mind blown. Our space telescope of the future is almost here." The music is suddenly reintroduced and overtakes all speech.
A male speaker begins by discussing the launch of something in late 2019 to French Guiana, noting it will be far from Earth, unlike the Hubble. He mentions it will be bigger and more complex.

The clip begins with a male speaker introducing the names "Einstein and Hubble." He continues with a description of a supernova and its host galaxy, explaining that a supernova involves a star "completely blowing itself apart" and becoming "brighter than the galaxy it's in combined," expressing awe.

A male speaker starts describing a graph and explains that "over time, the expansion of the universe has been changing." His tone is informative and explanatory. He adds that the further back in time you look, the more distant galaxies move away from us with a high velocity, some as fast as 40 to 50% of the speed of light. He contrasts this with closer objects that don't move as quickly.
The clip starts with a male speaker describing something as "beautiful" and a "globular cluster" called "47 Tucanae". This is followed by an indistinct sound, possibly a movement or rustling noise.

The audio starts with a male speaker describing and comparing the size of telescopes to the Coliseum, expressing amazement with a "Wow, they're huge." He continues explaining an analogy using a balloon and galaxies, then mentions raisin bread from previous chapters. He says that things will be getting tough, and states that there are four possible models of the universe. The audio ends by mentioning decelerating and closed or open systems.

The audio features a single male speaker with a slightly elevated tone. He discusses concepts related to cosmology, including the possibility of "coasting along" or an "accelerating universe". He mentions the Hubble Ultra-Deep Field and notes two historical figures: Lemaitre, a Belgian cosmologist who predicted Hubble's Law, and George Gamow, who considered the physics of the Big Bang.

A male speaker begins in an informative tone, stating that the universe's temperature has cooled. He explains that we can measure the temperature of the edge of the universe using cosmic background radiation, noting it's only a few degrees Kelvin, many hundreds of degrees below zero. He specifies the number as about 2.73 Kelvin. The audio ends with a "hm" sound.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker identifying Robert Wilson and Arno Penzias standing in front of the Bell Labs horn-shaped antenna, from which they accidentally discovered the cosmic background radiation. He states that they received their Nobel Prize in physics for it and mentions the measured radiation is 2.73 Kelvin. The speaker speaks in a factual and somewhat formal tone.

The clip starts with a male speaker stating that an instrument in space called "COBE" measured something. He explains that the instrument, called the Cosmic Origins Background Explorer, saw "some smoothness to the universe" in temperature but also "inconsistencies."

The audio starts with an expression of interest. A male speaker ponders how the space of the universe could be shaped, questioning if it might be spherical, flat, or hyperbolic. He then wonders what the universe is comprised of, mentioning dark stuff. A male voice continues speaking, but what he is saying is not clear.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing cosmology, stating that "in the observable universe, only 5% is the stuff we can actually see" like "stars, galaxies, planets, superclusters, all that stuff." The tone is informative and slightly conversational.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing dark matter, stating that it comprises "27%" and dark energy comprises "two-thirds" of the universe's composition. He notes that we can detect it but not see it, making it difficult. He then labels this as a "new discovery, a new theory". The speaker speaks with a thoughtful tone.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the evolution of cosmological understanding across decades, mentioning "visible matter," "dark matter," and "dark energy." He is speaking in a conversational tone. This is followed by a mention of a "cartoon from NASA."

The clip begins with a male speaker adopting a humorous tone, discussing dark matter as a "mystery flavor" and suggesting that whoever solves it will win the Nobel Prize in Physics. Following the speech, there is music playing, seemingly belonging to the electronic genre.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker presenting "a neat image of the history of the universe," mentioning the "afterglow light" and "the first stars," followed by the "development of galaxies" and "dark energy accelerating expansion." This is followed by music playing.

The clip starts with a single male speaker in a lecturing tone, discussing four "fundamental forces" including gravity, the weak and strong nuclear forces, and the electromagnetic force. He poses a question about which is the weakest and then answers: "it would be gravity." The audio ends with a non-speech sound, possibly a cough.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker summarizing the previous segment on the Big Bang and directing listeners to the next episode. The speaker speaks with a casual, conversational tone. Then, another male speaker asks if the listener enjoyed the episode, promoting the playlist for other videos, also in a casual manner.
